Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 45088  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
July 2011 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of Bangladesh: Capacity 
Development for Bangladesh Bank 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 1 June 2011) 
 
Currency Unit  –  taka (Tk) 
Tk1.00  =  $0.014 
$1.00  =  Tk73.2 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  FSR  –  financial stability report 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TASF  –  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Finance (banking systems, money and capital markets) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability), 
governance (economic and financial governance), capacity 
development (institutional development) 
Location impact  –  National (high)  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  S.H. Rahman, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  B. Carrasco, Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division, SARD 
   
Team leader  H. Mukhopadhyay, Public Management Economist, SARD 
Team members  R. Nagpal, Senior Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
  S. Rahman, Senior Economics Officer, Bangladesh Resident Mission, SARD 
Peer reviewer  L. Song, Senior Economist, Office of Regional Economic Integration 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  requested  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to provide capacity development support to the Bangladesh Bank. An 
ADB mission visited Dhaka in March 2011 and finalized, in consultation with the senior staff of 
the Bangladesh Bank, the technical assistance (TA) impact, outcome, outputs, implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consultants.1 The TA is 
consistent with ADB strategy to support the government’s effort to deepen and diversify the 
finance  sector, make  it  more  efficient,  and  strengthen money  market  governance  and  the 
regulatory environment. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The global financial crisis of 2008 and 2009 has reopened the debate about the contours 
of monetary management by the central banks in avoiding systemic risk. The crisis raises two 
policy challenges for central banks: (i) how to modify monetary policy strategic frameworks to 
better prevent or mitigate the effects of financial crises and (ii) how to adjust central bank 
operational frameworks to cope with future crises.2 The use of a broad-based monetary policy 
strategic framework, supported by forward-looking indicators, has proven to be key to effectively 
managing challenges to monetary and financial stability in an uncertain environment. In general, 
the three main monetary policy objectives in a broad-based monetary policy strategic framework 
are  (i)  price  stability,  (ii)  gross  domestic  product  growth,  and,  more  recently,  (iii) financial 
stability.  The  Bangladesh  Bank,  which  was  set  up  on  16  December  1971,3 reiterated  its 
commitment to the three broad monetary policy objectives with policy rates—the repo and the 
reverse repo rates—as the main instruments of monetary policy, supported by other indirect 
instruments such as open market operations and reserve requirements4 The Bangladesh Bank 
has  sought  ADB  support  in  acquiring  important  building  blocks  encompassing  monetary 
management, systemic risk assessments, and financial sector supervision, supported by a 
learning-by-doing partnership between international experts and the Bangladesh Bank staff.5  
 
3.  The Bangladesh Bank lacks adequate capacity in implementing a broad-based monetary 
policy framework that includes financial system oversight. In the area of conventional monetary 
management, the Bangladesh Bank needs to improve its internal capacity to formulate and 
implement monetary and exchange rate policy, including strengthening its capacity to monitor 
market liquidity based on market expectations about growth and inflation. Similarly, financial 
system oversight requires tighter supervision in many areas: (i) sustained improvements in 
information collection through market surveys and the use of the stress-testing methodology; (ii) 
improved  supervision  through  risk-based  supervision,  as  opposed  to  compliance-based 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 July 2011. 
2   International Monetary Fund. 2010. Central Banking Lessons from the Crisis. Washington, DC. 
3  Bangladesh Bank Order P.O. No. 127 of 1972. 
4  The Bangladesh Bank reiterated its vision in its strategic plan for 2010–2014 “to develop continually as a forward-
looking central bank with competent and committed professional of high ethical standards, conducting monetary 
management  and  financial  sector  supervision  to  maintain  price  stability  and  financial  system  robustness, 
supporting rapid broad-based inclusive economic growth, employment generation, and poverty eradication in 
Bangladesh.” See also A. Rahman. 2010. Bangladesh’s Monetary Policy in Pursuit of Inclusive Growth. Lecture 
delivered at the seminar organized by the Bangladesh German Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Dhaka 
(17 August). 
5  S. Brunschwig, B. Carrasco, T. Hayashi, and H. Mukhopadhyay. 2011. The Global Financial Crisis: Impact on Asia 
and the Emerging Consensus. South Asia Working Paper Series No. 3. Manila: ADB. The working paper provides 
a detailed discussion on issues pertaining to the operational framework of central banks.

2   
supervision;  and  (iii)  improved  assessment  of  banks’  risk  profiles. 6  Consequently,  the 
Bangladesh  Bank  requires  sustained  capacity  development  initiatives  to  carry  out  its  core 
functions efficiently. 
 
4.  The Bangladesh Bank has acknowledged that (i) inadequate training, professionalism, 
and a shortage of specialists; (ii) inadequate human resource policy including on training needs 
assessment;  and  (iii)  improper  workload  distribution  causing  dependency  on  only  a  few 
experienced  staff  may  constrain  the  smooth  conduct  of  monetary  management  and  other 
central bank functions.7 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The impact of the TA will be the improved conduct of monetary policy. The performance 
indicators are (i) a policy paper on an inflation management framework detailing operational 
procedures in line with the broad monetary policy objectives that go beyond traditional inflation 
targeting8 and (ii) a framework for finance sector risk management and assessment in place. 
The outcome of the TA will be strengthened in-house capacity of the Bangladesh Bank, which is 
necessary to improve the conduct of monetary policy by addressing its multiple objectives. 
Thus,  the  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  assessed  by  institutional  structures  and  guidelines 
developed on (i) preparing biannual financial stability reports (FSRs), (ii) carrying out surveys of 
business  and  inflation  expectations  at  regular  intervals,  (iii)  implementing  revised  banking 
regulations in line with international best practices, and (iv) publishing a few well-articulated 
policy and strategy papers on relevant topics by the Bangladesh Bank staff. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
6.  The TA will support implementing a capacity development plan for the Bangladesh Bank, 
which is necessary to improve the conduct of monetary policy in Bangladesh. This will be 
achieved by adopting a comprehensive, two-pronged approach. First, the TA will help the 
Bangladesh Bank to improve its internal capacity by providing training to selected staff on 
(i) preparing  high-quality  technical  reports  and  guidelines  covering  conventional  monetary 
management and financial supervision,9 (ii) carrying out the technical analysis and surveys 
necessary to  prepare these reports  and guidelines; and  (iii)  implementing  new  supervision 
                                                
6  International Monetary Fund. 2009. Bangladesh: Financial System Stability Assessment. Washington, DC. 
7  Bangladesh Bank. 2009. Strategic Plan: 2010–2014. 
8  Inflation targeting is a policy framework designed to stabilize inflation and is based on a monetary policy that 
supports an announced medium-term inflation target. In pursuing a traditional strategy targeting inflation, countries 
commit themselves to price stability as the main objective of monetary policy, stipulating that medium- to long-term 
inflation is where an inflation target is set. Policy rates are adjusted in response to deviations in inflation and growth 
from their targets. An emphasis on price stability over the long run could be one of the principal goals of monetary 
policy and monetary policy rules, but targets need to be designed carefully to ensure compatibility with other core 
objectives.  
9  The FSR is one such initiative. The purpose of the FSR is to identify at an early stage any vulnerability that could 
cause a crisis in the finance system and to recommend policy measures to address it. Conveying information on 
financial stability may be perceived as important to enhancing public understanding of financial stability and 
awareness of the role the central bank can play in ensuring it.

3 
guidelines.10 Second, the TA will support the dissemination of new initiatives and monetary 
management tools through workshops and conferences. 
 
7.  The outputs of the TA fall into four groups: (i) preparing the FSRs,11 (ii) preparing an 
inflation management framework, (iii) designing new banking supervision guidelines, and (iv) 
upgrading the skills those are crucial for either preparing these reports and frameworks in the 
future or for implementing new guidelines. The last group includes (i) designing and carrying out 
surveys of business and inflation expectations, including producing the reports on the first 
surveys; (ii) designing a set of macroprudential policies and instruments, which are important for 
improved financial supervision;12 (iii) implementing regulations on banking supervision; and (iv) 
improving writing and editing capacity. The TA will further upgrade skills by organizing field and 
exposure training for selected staff in other central banks in the regional countries. 
 
8.  A unique feature of this TA is that the outputs, while guided by international consultants, 
will  be  joint  products  emanating  from  core  partnerships  and  collaboration  between  the 
consultants and the staff of the Bangladesh Bank defined across each of the major outputs. This 
will be important for ensuring full ownership and understanding of TA deliverables by the staff of 
the Bangladesh Bank, and to ensure the effective rollout and sustainability of these initiatives 
once the consultants' work is complete. 
 
9.  The effective implementation of the TA crucially hinges on certain major assumptions: (i) 
the  Bangladesh  Bank’s  long-term  commitment  to  implementing  reforms  in  monetary 
management; (ii) no circumstances such as a banking crisis in the country that would force the 
Bangladesh Bank to shift its reform agenda; (iii) necessary human resources, hardware, and 
software  being  made  available  and  maintained  by  the  government;  and  (iv) necessary 
institutional arrangements with other central banks being in place for training. Major risks are (i) 
that the Bangladesh Bank may not sustain long-term capacity to address emerging monetary 
policy challenges and (ii) that the Bangladesh Bank may be unable to recruit or make suitable 
use of key staff to work with the consultants toward implementing TA initiatives.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $545,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV).  The remaining $45,000 will be 
contributed  by  the  government,  which  will  provide  counterpart  staff  remuneration,  office 
accommodation  and  supplies,  transport,  and  other  logistical  support.  The  detailed  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
 
 
                                                
10 Redesigning and implementing the banking supervision regulation is one of the tasks in this category, including the 
consolidated supervision of banking groups. All central banks are still designing recommendations to improve the 
conduct of both prudential supervision and consumer protection.  
11 A typical FSR starts with an overview of key developments affecting the country’s financial system. This is followed 
by sections that (i) review the provision of financial services in the economy, (ii) identify key risks to the financial 
system, (iii) assess the resilience of the system, and (iv) consider policies that can help safeguard stability. FSRs 
need to be periodic exercises reviewing the nature, magnitude, and implications of risks that have a bearing on the 
macroeconomic environment, financial institutions, markets, and infrastructure. Thus, proper capacity development 
and training of the trainers are crucial for sustaining this initiative. 
12 Macroprudential policy broadens the perspective of traditional prudential policy away from individual institutions 
and considers a systematic approach to promote sound practices and limit excessive risk-taking in the economy 
(see Bank for International Settlements. 2010. 80th Annual Report. Basel).

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The Bangladesh Bank will be the executing agency for the TA. Implementation will be 
supervised by a steering committee chaired by the deputy governor dealing with monetary 
policy. The Bangladesh Bank will form the committee before the TA consultants are engaged. A 
project implementation unit will be set up, also before the consultants are engaged, to supervise 
and  coordinate  the  TA.  The  steering  committee  will  nominate  key  senior  officials  from 
concerned departments to manage the unit. The executing agency will provide office space, a 
conference/workshop venue, furniture, equipment, and counterpart staff for the TA.  
 
12.  Twenty person-months of consultancy will be required, 8 person-months international 
and  12 national.  All  consultants  will  be  hired  on  individual  and  intermittent  bases.13 The 
international  consultants  will  be  a  monetary  management  specialist  and  a  finance  sector 
specialist.14 The national consultants will be a survey expert and an economics editor. The 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Appendix 3 provides the terms of reference. 
Moreover, senior resource persons from central banks will be invited for the conference. All 
procurement  of  equipment  will  be  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and handed over to the executing agency on 
TA completion. Disbursement under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be 
implemented over 2 years and is expected to commence in September 2011. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for Capacity Development for Bangladesh Bank, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                
13 The requirements are so diverse and specialized that no single firm is expected to have all required expertise. 
14 The consultants are expected to coordinate closely and draw inputs from another project preparatory TA provided 
by ADB on the development of capital markets in Bangladesh.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Monetary management specialist (5 person-months). The specialist will have proven 
experience  in  advising  central  banks  on  issues  pertaining  to  monetary  management.  The 
specialist will have at least 7 years of experience heading projects in relevant areas and a 
proper educational background in monetary management/financial sector supervision. Major 
responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  take the lead in publishing the first financial stability report, 
(ii)  design the framework for the financial stability report in collaboration with the 
finance sector specialist,  
(iii)  take  the  lead  in  designing  the  macroprudential  policies  and  instruments  in 
collaboration with the finance sector specialist, 
(iv)  prepare a detailed training manual on items (i) and (ii) in collaboration with the 
finance sector specialist, 
(v)  prepare a policy paper on inflation management including various options for 
inflation targeting in a broader framework, 
(vi)  prepare the revised risk-based banking supervision regulations in collaboration 
with the finance sector specialist, 
(vii)  guide the survey expert’s designing of the surveys of business and inflation 
expectations, 
(viii)  guide the survey expert’s preparing reports on survey results,  
(ix)  prepare terms of reference for the study tours,  
(x)  conducts necessary training sessions for the staff of the Bangladesh Bank, and 
(xi)  submit periodic reports. 
 
2.  Financial  sector  specialist  (3  person-months).  The  specialist  will  have  proven 
experience in advising central banks on issues pertaining to the finance sector, especially in 
assessing systemic risks. The specialist will have at least 7 years of experience in heading 
projects  in  the  relevant  areas  and  a  proper  educational  background  in  monetary 
management/financial sector supervision. Major responsibilities include the following: 
(i)  assist the monetary management specialist in designing the framework for the 
financial stability report,  
(ii)  assist  the monetary management  specialist  in designing  the macroprudential 
policies and instruments, 
(iii)  prepare  a  detailed  training  manual  on  (i)  and  (ii)  in  collaboration  with  the 
monetary management specialist, 
(iv)  draft the relevant portions of the first financial stability report, 
(v)  prepare  a  comprehensive  report  on  strengthening  the  government  securities 
market including identifying sources of demand from pension and provident funds 
and others, 
(vi)  assist the monetary management specialist in revising regulations on banking 
supervision,  
(vii)  conduct necessary training sessions for the staff of the Bangladesh Bank, and 
(viii)  submit periodic reports. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
3.  Survey expert (5 person-months). The expert will have proven experience in designing 
big surveys and analyzing the results in a comprehensive manner. The expert will have at least

Appendix 3  9 
7 years of experience in heading projects in the relevant areas. Major responsibilities include 
the following: 
(i)  help the monetary management expert design the survey questionnaires,  
(ii)  prepare the survey designs including the selection of the samples, 
(iii)  supervise the field surveys,  
(iv)  help prepare a detailed report on survey results, and 
(v)  submit periodic reports. 
 
4.  Economics editor (7 person-months). The editor will have proven experience in editing 
research papers and reports. The editor will train the research staff on writing and presentation 
skills and will prepare a manual on style and other relevant editorial matters. Finally, the editor 
will help edit selected research papers and reports prepared by the staff of the Bangladesh 
Bank and the conference volume.
